verses.text: I will give thanks to the LORD with all my heart; I will tell of all your wonderful deeds.
verses.comment: David begins the Psalm with wholehearted thanksgiving. The expression is reminiscent of worship that involves the whole self, both internal devotion and outward proclamation. In Christian tradition, such praise points forward to the fullness of worship in heaven (see Revelation 5:11-14).

verses.text: I will rejoice and be glad in you; I will sing praise to your name, O Most High.
verses.comment: Singing praise to the 'Most High' points to God's supreme authority. In Christian interpretation, such titles are seen as ultimately fulfilled in Christ, who is exalted above every name (Philippians 2:9-11).

verses.text: When my enemies turn back, they stumble and perish before your presence.
verses.comment: God's actual presence ensures the defeat of evil. For Christians, this foreshadows the final victory over sin and death through Christ's resurrection (1 Corinthians 15:54-57).

verses.text: For you have maintained my just cause; you sit on the throne judging righteously.
verses.comment: The image of God as righteous judge also points to the notion of a final judgment, as emphasized in both Old and New Testaments (Matthew 25:31-46). Believers trust God's justice, which requires not only faith but a life lived in accordance with His will.

verses.text: You have rebuked the nations, you have destroyed the wicked; you have blotted out their name forever and ever.
verses.comment: The permanence of God's judgment reveals the seriousness of sin. The theme of having one's name blotted out connects with Revelation 20:15, where only those written in the book of life are spared.

verses.text: The enemy is finished—ruins everlasting. You uprooted their cities; even the memory of them has perished.
verses.comment: This reflects God's ultimate victory over evil, and foreshadows the future state where nothing opposed to God persists (cf. Isaiah 65:17; Revelation 21:1-4).

verses.text: But the LORD sits enthroned forever; he has established his throne for judgment.
verses.comment: Unlike human rulers, God's reign is eternal. This unending kingship is ultimately fulfilled in the Messiah’s everlasting kingdom (Luke 1:33; Hebrews 1:8).

verses.text: He will judge the world with righteousness; he will execute judgment for the peoples with uprightness.
verses.comment: This universal judgment highlights God’s justice and his impartiality. The New Testament reveals that this judgment will be given to Christ (Acts 17:31).

verses.text: The LORD is a stronghold for the oppressed, a refuge in times of trouble.
verses.comment: God's care for the afflicted sets the standard for how his followers are to care for the marginalized (see Matthew 25:40). Many see a spiritual meaning here of God being the savior and defender of His people.

verses.text: Those who know your name put their trust in you, for you, LORD, have not forsaken those who seek you.
verses.comment: To ‘know God’s name’ in the biblical sense is to have an intimate relationship with Him. Jesus promises, 'I am with you always' (Matthew 28:20), showing God’s faithfulness to those who honestly seek him.

verses.text: Sing praises to the LORD, who dwells in Zion; declare among the peoples what he has done.
verses.comment: God's presence in Zion (Jerusalem) foreshadows how God would dwell among humanity in a special way. Christian tradition sees this fulfilled in the Incarnation and the Church, the new spiritual Zion (Hebrews 12:22).

verses.text: For he who avenges blood remembers them; he does not forget the cry of the afflicted.
verses.comment: God's justice is both personal and compassionate; He does not overlook the pain of the innocent shedding of blood. The cry of the afflicted echoes in Christ's solidarity with sufferers (Hebrews 4:15).

verses.text: Be gracious to me, O LORD! See the affliction I suffer from those who hate me, you who lift me up from the gates of death,
verses.comment: The plea for uniquely saving grace anticipates the salvation accomplished through Jesus, who redeems us from death and hell (Ephesians 2:4-6).

verses.text: so that I may recount all your praises, that in the gates of the daughter of Zion I may rejoice in your salvation.
verses.comment: Experiencing God’s salvation leads to public worship, not private gratitude. The 'gates of the daughter of Zion' refer to the community of believers, calling to mind the gathering of the people of God.

verses.text: The nations have sunk into the pit they made; in the net they hid, their own foot has been caught.
verses.comment: This describes the biblical principle of divine justice, where the wicked fall by their own traps. Proverbs 26:27 and Galatians 6:7 echo this truth.

verses.text: The LORD is known by the judgment he executes; the wicked are snared in the work of their own hands. Meditation. Selah.
verses.comment: 'Meditation. Selah.' calls the worshiper to ponder God’s justice. The phrase reminds Christians to consider both God’s judgments and mercy, encouraging examination of conscience.

verses.text: The wicked shall return to Sheol, all the nations that forget God.
verses.comment: Sheol symbolizes the realm of the dead. In Christian revelation, deliberate separation from God leads to judgment (see Matthew 10:28).

verses.text: For the needy shall not always be forgotten, nor shall the hope of the poor perish forever.
verses.comment: The assurance given here is echoed in Mary’s Magnificat (Luke 1:52-53), where God exalts the humble and fills the hungry with good things.

verses.text: Arise, O LORD! Do not let man prevail; let the nations be judged before you.
verses.comment: The call for God to rise and judge the nations is a plea for divine intervention. This expectation finds fulfillment in Christ's ultimate return as Judge (Acts 10:42).

verses.text: Put terror in them, O LORD! Let the nations know they are only human. Selah.
verses.comment: The Psalm ends with a prayer for humility among the nations. Recognizing humanity’s limitations points to the need for God’s grace and the humility required for true worship, as Jesus taught (Matthew 5:3).
